Chromatic splitting, redux

Jul 23, 2019

In the previous post, I asked the following question: let be the “chromatic splitting element” (I don’t know a better name); then, is , where I view as ? I think the answer is no.

This comes from a discussion I had with Mark about this. He suggested calculating in the localized Adams-Novikov spectral sequence. One reason is that admits a good description in the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for : it’s represented in the cobar complex by the element . Recall how one goes from the cobar complex to the Morava spectral sequence: this comes from a map of cosimplicial objects , where denotes a Morava E-theory of height . We’ll use the Morava E-theory associated to the Honda formal group law.

First, recall that , where . It follows from Landweber exactness that . The map of cosimplicial objects at level one is a map . This is implemented by the map which sends to the following map . Recall that , where ; write as , with being Teichmuller lifts of elements . The map which defines sends to , where is the periodicity generator. Note that since conjugation by in corresponds to applying Frobenius to the coefficients, and , the element is in fact Galois invariant, and hence lives in .

The upshot of this is that in the Morava spectral sequence, the class is given by the crossed homomorphism sending to . Note that this map factors through — the higher s don’t play a role in this.

What would be sufficient is if the map is also given by sending to . The case when is very easy (where the answer is positive), but the case when becomes interesting. In this case, we can write as . Let’s call the first term , and the second term . Then the inclusion is given by sending this to , where is the Frobenius (acting via the Teichmuller lift). The determinant map therefore sends to

and consequently (note that ) the map sends to . This isn’t the same as , and isn’t even going to be homologous to it. So is not , and in fact, will not be in for .

However, our calculation above has shown that is homologous to . In fact, to get the representation of in general, note that the matrix in corresponding to has entries

Therefore, is homologous to the polynomial in the s (with each term appropriately scaled by powers of . This is, I think, the best that one could say in general about the relationship between and . I guess I should’ve expected this from the outset, but this turned out to be a cute calculation, so I’m not too bothered.
